<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 74, 601, 92]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 134, 561, 153]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 166, 242, 184]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 196, 386, 214]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 214, 583, 250]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 272, 228, 289]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 292, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 345, 495, 383]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 411, 386, 429]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 435, 536, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 488, 336, 506]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 510, 430, 579]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 611, 596, 630]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 644, 158, 662]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 672, 584, 724]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 766, 243, 784]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 792, 596, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C\] \[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 418, 94]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(4\left|7x - 3\right| - 5 = 9.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 97, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 586, 405]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the equation \(y = kx^2\). When \(x = 1 + \sqrt{2}\), \(y = 1 - \sqrt{2}\). Find the value of \(k\), giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{c}\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 433, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The points \(A, B\) and \(C\) have coordinates \((2, 6), (6, 1)\) and \((p, q)\) respectively. Given that \(B\) is the mid-point of \(AC\), find the equation of the line that passes through \(C\) and is perpendicular to \(AB\). Give your answer in the form \(ax + by = c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 426, 96, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 146, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 742, 445]]<|/det|>
Find the range of values of \(x\) satisfying the inequality \((5x - 1)(6 - x) < 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 426, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 146, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation \((2k + 1)x^{2} - 4kx + 2k - 1 = 0\), where \(k \neq -\frac{1}{2}\), has distinct, real roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 84, 848, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 428, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the graph of \(y = a\tan bx + c\). The graph has vertical asymptotes at \(x = - 4\pi\) and \(x = 4\pi\) and passes through the points \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 144, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 457, 494]]<|/det|>
Write down the period of \(a\tan bx + c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 146, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 384, 587]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 570, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 6x^{3} + ax^{2} - 52x + b\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers. It is given that \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divisible by \(2x - 3\) and that \(\mathrm{p}'(1) = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 122, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 122, 366, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 720, 524]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS PART OF THE QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 144, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 544, 555]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\), factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) fully.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 185, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 690, 92]]<|/det|>
Write down the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\lg (5x - 3)\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 211, 181, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 472, 230]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\lg (5x - 3) = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 144, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\log_{y}x = 4 + \frac{1}{2}\log_{y}64 + \log_{y}162,\) where \(y > 0\). Find an expression for \(y\) in terms of \(x\). Simplify your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 138, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 75, 500, 96]]<|/det|>
Differentiate \(y = 2x\mathrm{e}^{4x}\) with respect to \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 275, 144, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 271, 339, 300]]<|/det|>
Hence find \(\int x\mathrm{e}^{4x}\mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 276, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 534, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the unit vector in the direction of \(40\mathbf{i} - 9\mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of points \(P\) and \(Q\) relative to an origin \(O\) are \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{q}\) respectively. The point \(R\) lies on the line \(PQ\) and is between \(P\) and \(Q\) such that \(\frac{PR}{PQ} = k\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 327, 181, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 327, 551, 348]]<|/det|>
Write down the set of all possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 327, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 451, 181, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 451, 843, 472]]<|/det|>
Given that the position vector of \(R\) relative to \(O\) is \(\lambda \mathbf{p} + \mu \mathbf{q}\) show that \(\lambda + \mu = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 451, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 87, 823, 351]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = 3 + 2x - x^{2}\). The point \(A\) lies on the curve and has an \(x\)-coordinate of 1.5. The tangent to the curve at \(A\) meets the \(x\)-axis at \(B\). The curve meets the \(x\)-axis at \(C\). Find the area of the shaded region. [10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 453, 88]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The sum of the first 20 terms of an arithmetic progression is 1100. The sum of the first 70 terms is 14 350. Find the 12th term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of a geometric progression are \(x + 6, \quad x - 9, \quad \frac{1}{2} (x + 1)\). Show that \(x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
satisfies the equation \(x^{2} - 43x + 156 = 0\). Hence show that a sum to infinity exists for each possible value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 472, 89]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 97, 631, 183]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 199, 920, 249]]<|/det|>
A container is a half-cylinder, open as shown. It has length \(y\) and uniform cross-section of radius \(x\). The volume of the container is \(25 000\). Given that \(x\) and \(y\) can vary and that the outer surface area, \(S\), of the container has a minimum value, find this value. [8]
